column.name: score
column.description: Score of a given neighbour. \\ If the cross-match is based only on geometric distance, the score is simply the order of the neighbours ordered by distance from the Gaia source. The nearest neighbour would have score=1, the second nearest would have score=2.\\ For the first Gaia release the score will be a likelihood ratio based on geometric distance and local density of the external catalogue. In the latter case the higher the score, the most probable the match is.\\

table.name: tycho2
table.description:
The Tycho-2 Catalogue is an astrometric reference catalogue containing positions and proper motions as well as two-colour photometric data for the 2.5 million brightest stars in the sky. The Tycho-2 positions and magnitudes are based on precisely the same observations as the original Tycho Catalogue (hereafter Tycho-1; see Cat. I/239)) collected by the star mapper of the ESA Hipparcos satellite, but Tycho-2 is much bigger and slightly more precise, owing to a more advanced reduction technique. Components of double stars with separations down to 0.8 arcsec are included. Proper motions precise to about 2.5 mas/yr are given as derived from a comparison with the Astrographic Catalogue and 143 other ground-based astrometric catalogues, all reduced to the Hipparcos celestial coordinate system. Tycho-2 supersedes in most applications Tycho-1, as well as the ACT (Cat. I/246) and TRC (Cat. I/250) catalogues based on Tycho-1. Supplement-1 lists stars from the Hipparcos and Tycho-1 Catalogues which are not in Tycho-2. Supplement-2 lists 1146 Tycho-1 stars which are probably either false or heavily disturbed.
For more information, please consult the Tycho-2 home page: http://www.astro.ku.dk/~erik/Tycho-2

column.name: dec
column.description: Observed Tycho-2 Declination, ICRS

column.name: id
column.description: Tycho 2 identifier. The TYC identifier is constructed from the GSC region number (TYC1), the running number within the region (TYC2) and a component identifier (TYC3) which is normally 1. Some non-GSC running numbers were constructed for the first Tycho Catalogue and for Tycho-2. The recommended star designation contains a hyphen between the TYC numbers, e.g. TYC 1-13-1.

column.name: ra
column.description: Observed Tycho-2 Right Ascension, ICRS

column.name: bt_mag
column.description:
[2.183,16.581]? Tycho-2 BT magnitude
Blank when no magnitude is available. Either BTmag or VTmag is always given. Approximate Johnson photometry may be obtained as: V = VT -0.090*(BT-VT) B-V = 0.850*(BT-VT) Consult Sect 1.3 of Vol 1 of "The Hipparcos and Tycho Catalogues", ESA SP-1200, 1997, for details.

column.name: ccdm
column.description:
CCDM component identifier for HIP stars
The CCDM component identifiers for double or multiple Hipparcos stars contributing to this Tycho-2 entry. For photocentre solutions, all components within 0.8 arcsec contribute. For double star solutions any unresolved component within 0.8 arcsec contributes. For single star solutions, the predicted signal from close stars were normally subtracted in the analysis of the photon counts and such stars therefore do not contribute to the solution. The components are given in lexical order.

column.name: corr
column.description: [-1,1] correlation (RAdeg,DEdeg)

column.name: de_deg
column.description: Observed Tycho-2 Declination, ICRS

column.name: de_mdeg
column.description:
[]? Mean Decl, ICRS, at epoch=J2000
The mean position is a weighted mean for the catalogues contributing to the proper motion determination. This mean has then been brought to epoch 2000.0 by the computed proper motion. See Note(2) above for details. Tycho-2 is one of the several catalogues used to determine the mean position and proper motion. The observed Tycho-2 position is given in the fields RAdeg and DEdeg.

column.name: e_bt_mag
column.description:
[0.014,1.977]? s.e. of BT
Blank when no magnitude is available. Either BTmag or VTmag is always given. Approximate Johnson photometry may be obtained as: V = VT -0.090*(BT-VT) B-V = 0.850*(BT-VT) Consult Sect 1.3 of Vol 1 of "The Hipparcos and Tycho Catalogues", ESA SP-1200, 1997, for details.

column.name: e_de_deg
column.description: s.e. of observed Tycho-2 Dec. The errors are based on error models.

column.name: e_de_mdeg
column.description: [1,184]? s.e. of Dec at mean epoch. The errors are based on error models.

column.name: ep_de_1990
column.description: [0.72,2.36] epoch-1990 of DEdeg

column.name: ep_de_m
column.description: [1911.94,1992.01]? mean epoch of Dec. The mean epochs are given in Julian years.

column.name: e_pm_de
column.description: [0.2,10.3]? s.e. of proper motion in Dec. The errors are based on error models.

column.name: e_pm_ra
column.description: [0.2,11.5]? s.e. prop mot in RA*cos(dec).The errors are based on error models.

column.name: ep_ra_1990
column.description: [0.81,2.13] epoch-1990 of RAdeg

column.name: ep_ra_m
column.description: [1915.95,1992.53]? mean epoch of RA. The mean epochs are given in Julian years.

column.name: e_ra_deg
column.description: s.e.RA*cos(dec), of observed Tycho-2 RA. The errors are based on error models.

column.name: e_ra_mdeg
column.description: [3,183]? s.e. RA*cos(dec),at mean epoch. The errors are based on error models.

column.name: e_vt_mag
column.description:
[0.009,1.468]? s.e. of VT
Blank when no magnitude is available. Either BTmag or VTmag is always given. Approximate Johnson photometry may be obtained as: V = VT -0.090*(BT-VT) B-V = 0.850*(BT-VT) Consult Sect 1.3 of Vol 1 of "The Hipparcos and Tycho Catalogues", ESA SP-1200, 1997, for details.

column.name: hip
column.description: [1,120404]? Hipparcos number

column.name: num
column.description: [2,36]? Number of positions used

column.name: pflag
column.description:
[ PX] mean position flag
' ' = normal mean position and proper motion. 'P' = the mean position, proper motion, etc., refer to the photocentre of two Tycho-2 entries, where the BT magnitudes were used in weighting the positions. 'X' = no mean position, no proper motion.

column.name: pm_de
column.description:
? Proper motion in Dec
Some Hipparcos stars (having a positive number in the HIP column) have no proper motions; these are virtually all in multiple systems.

column.name: pm_ra
column.description:
? Proper motion in RA*cos(dec)
Some Hipparcos stars (having a positive number in the HIP column) have no proper motions; these are virtually all in multiple systems.

column.name: posflg
column.description:
[ DP] type of Tycho-2 solution
' ' = normal treatment, close stars were subtracted when possible. 'D' = double star treatment. Two stars were found. The companion is normally included as a separate Tycho-2 entry, but may have been rejected. 'P' = photocentre treatment, close stars were not subtracted. This special treatment was applied to known or suspected doubles which were not successfully (or reliably) resolved in the Tycho-2 double star processing.

column.name: prox
column.description:
[3,999] proximity indicator
Distance in units of 100 mas to the nearest entry in the Tycho-2 main catalogue or supplement. The distance is computed for the epoch 1991.25. A value of 999 (i.e. 99.9 arcsec) is given if the distance exceeds 99.9 arcsec.

column.name: q_de_mdeg
column.description:
[0.0,9.9]? Goodness of fit for mean Dec
This goodness of fit is the ratio of the scatter-based and the model-based error. It is only defined when Num > 2. Values exceeding 9.9 are truncated to 9.9.

column.name: q_pm_de
column.description:
[0.0,9.9]? Goodness of fit for pmDE
This goodness of fit is the ratio of the scatter-based and the model-based error. It is only defined when Num > 2. Values exceeding 9.9 are truncated to 9.9.

column.name: q_pm_ra
column.description:
[0.0,9.9]? Goodness of fit for pmRA
This goodness of fit is the ratio of the scatter-based and the model-based error. It is only defined when Num > 2. Values exceeding 9.9 are truncated to 9.9.

column.name: q_ra_mdeg
column.description:
[0.0,9.9]? Goodness of fit for mean RA
This goodness of fit is the ratio of the scatter-based and the model-based error. It is only defined when Num > 2. Values exceeding 9.9 are truncated to 9.9.

column.name: ra_deg
column.description: Observed Tycho-2 Right Ascension, ICRS

column.name: ra_mdeg
column.description:
[]? Mean Right Asc, ICRS, epoch=J2000
The mean position is a weighted mean for the catalogues contributing to the proper motion determination. This mean has then been brought to epoch 2000.0 by the computed proper motion. See Note(2) above for details. Tycho-2 is one of the several catalogues used to determine the mean position and proper motion. The observed Tycho-2 position is given in the fields RAdeg and DEdeg.

column.name: tyc
column.description:
[T] Tycho-1 star
' ' = no Tycho-1 star was found within 0.8 arcsec (quality 1-8) or 2.4 arcsec (quality 9). 'T' = this is a Tycho-1 star. The Tycho-1 identifier is given in the beginning of the record. For Tycho-1 stars, resolved in Tycho-2 as a close pair, both components are flagged as a Tycho-1 star and the Tycho-1 TYC3 is assigned to the brightest (VT) component. The HIP-only stars given in Tycho-1 are not flagged as Tycho-1 stars.

column.name: tyc1
column.description:

The TYC identifier is constructed from the GSC region number (TYC1), the running number within the region (TYC2) and a component identifier (TYC3) which is normally 1. Some non-GSC running numbers were constructed for the first Tycho Catalogue and for Tycho-2. The recommended star designation contains a hyphen between the TYC numbers, e.g. TYC 1-13-1.

column.description:

The TYC identifier is constructed from the GSC region number (TYC1), the running number within the region (TYC2) and a component identifier (TYC3) which is normally 1. Some non-GSC running numbers were constructed for the first Tycho Catalogue and for Tycho-2. The recommended star designation contains a hyphen between the TYC numbers, e.g. TYC 1-13-1.

column.name: tyc3

Some non-GSC running numbers were constructed for the first Tycho Catalogue and for Tycho-2. The recommended star designation contains a hyphen between the TYC numbers, e.g. TYC 1-13-1.

column.name: vt_mag
column.description:
[1.905,15.193]? Tycho-2 VT magnitude
Blank when no magnitude is available. Either BTmag or VTmag is always given. Approximate Johnson photometry may be obtained as: V = VT -0.090*(BT-VT) B-V = 0.850*(BT-VT) Consult Sect 1.3 of Vol 1 of "The Hipparcos and Tycho Catalogues", ESA SP-1200, 1997, for details.

table.name: ucac4_original_valid
table.description:
UCAC4 Catalogue (Zacharias N., et al. 2013, AJ 145, 44)
UCAC4 is a compiled, all-sky star catalog covering mainly the 8 to 16 magnitude range in a single bandpass between V and R. Positional errors are about 15 to 20 mas for stars in the 10 to 14 mag range. Proper motions have been derived for most of the about 113 million stars utilizing about 140 other star catalogs with significant epoch difference to the UCAC CCD observations. Since the publication of UCAC4 in august 2012, the authors advised to apply the following corrections: - 2013 Mar 10, UCAC4 streak objects: Some objects in the UCAC4 catalog are already classi- fied as ”streak objects”. In an effort to identify artifacts in the catalog this issue has been further investigated by others; see for example (http://www.ap-i.net/skychart/en/news/ucac4 streak) - 2013 Feb: Data for a small number of high proper motion stars have been corrected. (http://www.usno.navy.mil/USNO/astrometry/optical-IR-prod/ucac) We applied both suggested corrections to the original files, the resulting UCAC4 version has 113 728 883 objects

column.name: best_neighbour_multiplicity
column.description: The best-match to a Gaia source in an external catalogue is the source in the external catalogue that has the highest probability to be the best-match.\\ As the probability is based on positional and density properties, it could happen that there is more than one source in the external catalogue with the same probability.\\ Even if a single best-match is always chosen, this field tells the user if there were more "best" neighbours. Those neighbours can be found in the Neighbourhood table.

column.name: number_of_mates
column.description: Number of other Gaia sources that have as best-neighbour the same External Catalogue source.\\ In case there are no other Gaia sources with the same best-neighbour in the external catalogue, the number of mates is equal to zero.\\ Given the Gaia high angular resolution, it will happen that what appears as a single object in an external catalogue will be resolved by Gaia and as such will be the best-match of more than one Gaia object.

column.name: number_of_neighbours
column.description: Number of sources in the External Catalogue which match the Gaia source within position errors.\\ The identifiers of all the neighbours can be found in the Neighbourhood table.

table.name: dual
table.description: auxiliary table to be used as dummy "from"

table.name: gaia_source
table.description: This table has an entry for every Gaia observed source as listed in the MDB version from which the catalogue release has been generated. It contains the basic source parameters, that is only final data (no epoch data) and no spectra (neither final nor epoch). A copy of this table will be distributed to all the associated data centers. The contents of this table are extracted from MDB/CU1/Integrated/CompleteSource. As such, they are Gaia scientific data and should never be modified by CU9 processes.

column.name: dec
column.description: Latitude (Declination) $\delta$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: parallax
column.description: Absolute stellar parallax $\varpi$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: parallax_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_\varpi$ of absolute stellar parallax at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: phot_g_mean_mag
column.description: Mean magnitude in the G band. This is computed from the G-band mean flux applying the magnitude zero-point in the AB scale. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

column.name: pmdec
column.description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}: $\mu_{\delta}$

column.name: pmra
column.description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Right Ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}: $\mu_{\alpha*}$

column.name: ra
column.description: Longitude (Right Ascension) $\alpha$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: random_index
column.description:
Random index which can be used in order to select smaller subsets of the data that are still representative. This can be useful for validation (testing on 10 different random subsets), visualization (displaying 1% of the data) and exploring the data, without having to load/download all data.
The column should have non-repeating/unique long, preferably without any missing numbers between 0 and N-1 (where N is the numbers of rows).
This column should be just a counter which gets populated in a totatly random way.

column.name: astrometric_chi2_ac
column.description:
Astrometric goodness-of-fit ($\chi^2$) in the AC direction.
These $\chi^2$ values were computed for all accepted observations of the source, without taking into account the source $\tt excessNoise$ (if any). They do however take into account the attitude excess noise (if any) of each observation.

column.name: astrometric_chi2_al
column.description:
Astrometric goodness-of-fit ($\chi^2$) in the AL direction.
These $\chi^2$ values were computed for all accepted observations of the source, without taking into account the source $\tt excessNoise$ (if any). They do however take into account the attitude excess noise (if any) of each observation.

column.name: astrometric_delta_q
column.description:
In the HTPM solution $\tt deltaQ$ indicates the discrepancy between the Hipparcos data and the Gaia data when a single model of uniform space motion is fitted to both datasets. A large value of $\tt deltaQ$ could indicate non-linear motion (e.g.\ in a binary).
$\tt deltaQ$ shows how much the $\chi^2$ of the joint solution increases by fitting a single set of five astrometric parameters to the data, rather than two independent sets of five parameter each. See D. Michalik et al. 2014, \emph{Joint astrometric solution of Hipparcos and Gaia: A recipe for the Hundred Thousand Proper Motions project} (submitted to A\&A) for details.

column.name: astrometric_excess_noise
column.description:
This is the excess noise $\epsilon_i$ of the source. It measures how much the assumed observational noise in each observation must be (quadratically) increased in order to give $\chi^2=\nu$ in the astrometric solution of the source. A value of 0 signifies that the source is astrometrically well-behaved, i.e.\ that the residuals of the fit statistically agree with the assumed observational noise ($\chi^2\le\nu$).
The significance of $\tt excessNoise$ is given by $\tt excessNoiseSig$. If ${\tt excessNoiseSig}\le 2$ then $\tt excessNoise$ is probably not significant, and the source may be astrometrically well-behaved even if $\tt excessNoise$ is large.
Independent of the given value of $\tt excessNoise$, the `gaussianized chi-square $\tt f2$ is always calculated using ${\tt excessNoise}=0$.
The excess source noise is further explained in Sects.~3.6 and 5.1.2 of \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

column.name: astrometric_excess_noise_sig
column.description: A dimensionless measure ($D$) of the significance of the calculated $\tt excessNoise$ ($\epsilon_i$). A value $D>2$ indicates that the given $\tt excessNoise$ is probably significant.

column.name: astrometric_go_f
column.description:
$	t f2$ is the `gaussianized chi-square indicating the goodness-of-fit of the astrometric solution to the accepted data. For good fits, $	t f2$ should approximately follow a normal distribution with zero mean value and unit standard deviation. $	t f2$ values exceeding, say, +3 thus indicate a bad fit to the data. An alternative indicator of bad fits is the $	t excessNoise$ (see below).
The statistic $	t f2$ was computed from the goodness-of-fit statistic $\chi^2$ (see below) and $
u$, the number of degrees of freedom, according to the formula:
${m f2}=(9
u/2)^{1/2} [(\chi^2/
u)^{1/3} + 2 / (9
u) -1]$
This formula is the well-known cube-root transformation of the chi-square variable (E.B. Wilson \& M.M. Hilferty 1931, Proc. National Academy of Science, 17, 684). It is usually quoted to be valid for $
u > 30$, but is in fact useful for much smaller $
u$. The transformation of $(\chi^2,
u)$ to f2 eliminates the inconvenience of having the distribution (and hence the significance levels) depend on the additional variable $
u$, which is generally not the same for different sources.
For a source update with $N$ astrometric parameters (see ${	t paramsSolved}$), $\chi^2$ and $
u$ were computed as
$\chi^2 = {	t chi2}[0] + {	t chi2}[1]$,
$
u = {	t nObs}[0] + {	t nObs}[1] - N$.
The `unit weight error of the solution is given by $(\chi^2/
u)^{1/2}$, which is expected to be $\simeq 1.0$ for a good solution, but unlike f2 its distribution still depends on $
u$.
In AGIS the source update deals with bad fits (large $	t f2$) by adding $	t excessNoise$ to the formal observation noise. This effectively reduces the unit weight error of the fit to 1.0 and inflates the covariance of the estimated astrometric parameters correspondingly. However, the chi-square values ${	t chi2}[]$ used to calculate $	t f2$ do not take into account the $	t excessNoise$, and $	t f2$ can therefore always be used as a goodness-of-fit indicator of the source solution in AGIS. The excessNoise provides an alternative indicator of bad fits, although it may be 0 for good fits (unit weight error $\le 1$, roughly corresponding to negative $	t f2$). The actual amount of excess noise used in the fit (and covariance calculation) is given by $	t excessNoise$ if ${	t excessNoiseSig}>2$, otherwise it is 0 (even though $	t excessNoise$ may be positive).

column.name: astrometric_n_obs_ac
column.description: Total number of observations (= CCD transits) in AC that contributed to the astrometric solution of the source. The total number of observations may decrease as outliers are detected so this number refers to the total number of observations minus the number of outliers.

column.name: astrometric_n_obs_al
column.description: Total number of observations (= CCD transits) AL that contributed to the astrometric solution of the source. The total number of observations may decrease as outliers are detected so this number refers to the total number of observations minus the number of outliers.

column.name: astrometric_n_outliers_ac
column.description: Total number of outlier observations (= CCD transits) in AC (second element). Identified outliers were downweighted and did not contribute to the update of the source. An observation was regarded as an outlier if the downweighting factor was $<0.2$.

column.name: astrometric_n_outliers_al
column.description: Total number of outlier observations (= CCD transits) in AL. Identified outliers were downweighted and did not contribute to the update of the source. An observation was regarded as an outlier if the downweighting factor was $<0.2$.

column.name: astrometric_params_solved
column.description:
The 6 least-significant bits of ${\tt paramsSolved}$ indicate which astrometric parameters have been estimated for this source. A set bit means the parameter was updated, an unset bit means the parameter was not updated. The least-significant bit corresponds to $\alpha$. The table below shows the values of ${\tt paramsSolved}$ for relevant combinations of the parameters.
Each AGIS run starts with a target number $N$ (usually = 5) of astrometric parameters to solve for, with the following mapping:
\begin{tabular}{lccccccc} $N$ & ${\tt paramsSolved}$ & $\alpha$ & $\delta$ & $\varpi$ & $\mu_{\alpha*}$ & $\mu_\delta $ & $\mu_r$ \\\hline 2 & 3 & $\times$ & $\times$ & & & & \\ 3 & 7 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & & & \\ 4 & 27 & $\times$ & $\times$ & & $\times$ & $\times$ & \\ 5 & 31 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & \\ 6 & 63 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$\\\hline \end{tabular}
For each source, however, an $N$-parameter update could fail (e.g.\ because there is an insufficient number of observations or their temporal distribution does not allow the update) and in this case a fallback option with a smaller value of $N$ is attempted.

column.name: astrometric_primary_flag
column.description: Flag indicating if this source was used as a primary source ($\tt true$) or secondary source ($\tt false$). Only primary sources contribute to the estimation of attitude, calibration, and global parameters. The estimation of source parameters is otherwise done in exactly the same way for primary and secondary sources.

column.name: astrometric_priors_used
column.description: Type of prior used in the astrometric solution: \begin{itemize} \item 0: No prior used \item 1: Galaxy Bayesian Prior for parallax and proper motion \item 2: Galaxy Bayesian Prior for parallax and proper motion relaxed by factor 10 \item 3: Hipparcos prior for position \item 4: Hipparcos prior for position and proper motion \item 5: Tycho2 prior for position \item 6: Quasar prior for proper motion \end{itemize}

column.name: astrometric_rank_defect
column.description: The rank defect of the astrometric solution of the source. This should normally be zero, signaling that the rank of the least-squares system for the solution equals the number of estimated parameters (the binary digit sum of ${\tt paramsSolved}$). A positive value means that the astrometric solution of the source is most likely wrong.

column.name: astrometric_relegation_factor
column.description: Relegation factor of the source calculated as per Eq.~(118) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain} used for the primary selection process.

column.name: astrometric_weight_ac
column.description:
mean astrometric weight of the source in the AC direction
The mean astrometric weight of the source is calculated as per Eq.~(119) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

column.name: astrometric_weight_al
column.description:
mean astrometric weight of the source in the ALdirection.
The mean astrometric weight of the source is calculated as per Eq.~(119) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

column.name: dec_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_\delta$ of latitude (Declination) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: dec_parallax_corr
column.description: Correlation between declination and parallax in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: dec_pmdec_corr
column.description: Correlation between declination and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: dec_pmra_corr
column.description: Correlation between declination and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: matched_observations
column.description:
A given source will never be removed from the MDB catalog. Instead, it may simply be left without any matched observation, thus indicating that this source has e.g. been splitted into two, or that it may have been a parasitic source wrongly created in IDT.
This field indicates the number of observations (detection transits) that have been matched to a given Source during the last XM revision.
In particular, matchedObservations = 0 indicates a Source which has been merged to another one by IDU XM, MDB Integrator, etc.
Also, it is proposed to use matchedObservations = -1 to indicate that a given source has never been observed by Gaia (but it was included in the catalog from the IGSL, etc).

column.name: parallax_pmdec_corr
column.description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: parallax_pmra_corr
column.description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: phot_g_mean_flux
column.description: Mean flux in the G-band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

column.name: phot_g_mean_flux_error
column.description: Error on the mean flux in the G-band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

column.name: phot_g_n_obs
column.description: Number of observations that contributed to the G mean flux and mean flux error. This number will be set to 0 if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

column.name: phot_variable_flag
pmdec_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\delta}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: pmra_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\alpha*}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing right ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: pmra_pmdec_corr
column.description: Correlation between proper motion right ascension and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ra_dec_corr
column.description: Correlation between right ascension and declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ra_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_\alpha *$ of longitude (Right Ascension) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch} times $\cos(\delta)$.

column.name: ra_parallax_corr
column.description: Correlation between right ascension and parallax in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ra_pmdec_corr
column.description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ra_pmra_corr
column.description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ref_epoch
column.description: The reference epoch to which the astrometic source parameters are referred to expressed as a Julian Year in TCB.

column.name: scan_direction_mean_k1
column.description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
scanDirectionMean[$k-1$] is an angle between $-180^\circ/k$ and $+180^\circ/k$, giving the mean position angle of the scans at order $k$.
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

column.name: scan_direction_mean_k2
column.description:

column.name: scan_direction_strength_k1
column.description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

column.name: source_id
column.description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

column.name: dec
column.description: The declination at epoch and equinox J2000

column.name: ra
column.description: The right ascension at epoch and equinox J2000

column.name: source_id
column.description: Source identifier as defined in GAIA-CD-TN-ARI-BAS-020-01

column.name: aux_epc
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the EPC, false=no, true=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReference table. If yes, the number in the SourceCatalogIDs table is the number in EPC.

column.name: aux_gsc23
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the GSC2.3 cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the GSC2.3 id is in the SourceCatalogIDs as idGSC23.

column.name: aux_hip
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the Hipparcos catalog, 0=no, 1=yes=true.

column.name: aux_lqrf
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the CU3 QSO Aux cat GIQC, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idLQRF.

column.name: aux_ogle
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the OGLE cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idOGLE

column.name: aux_ppmxl
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the PPMXL cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idPPMXL

column.name: aux_sdss
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the SDSS cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idSDSS

column.name: aux_tmass
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the Two-MASS cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idTMASS.

column.name: aux_tycho
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in theTYCHO2 cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idTYCHO

column.name: aux_ucac
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the UCAC cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the iSourceCatalogIDs as idUCAC.

column.name: classification
column.description: Classification, simply a 0=star and 1=nonstar taken from different sources as given in the souceClass field

column.name: dec_epoch
column.description: The mean epoch of the declination Julian Year in TCB. Note if there are proper motions the actual position will be at J2000 to have a consistent catalog and this is provided if the user wishes to add new information or find the best position.

column.name: dec_error
column.description: The mean error in the declination at mean epoch

column.name: ecliptic_lat

column.name: galactic_lat

column.name: galactic_lon

column.name: mag_g_error
column.description: Estimated of error on G magnitude

column.name: mag_grvs
column.description: Estimated $G_rvs$ magnitude based on transformations in livelink document RLS 004

column.name: ra_epoch

column.name: solution_id
column.description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

column.name: source_classification
column.description: Code in IgslReferences that describes where this datapoint comes from.

column.name: source_mag_bj
column.description: Code in IgslReferences that describes where this magnitude comes from.

column.name: source_mag_g
column.description: Code in IgslReferences that describes which transformation used.

column.name: source_mag_grvs
column.description: Code in SourceCatalogIDs that describes where base magnitudes came from

column.name: source_mag_rf
column.description: Code in IgslReferences that describes where this magnitude comes from.

column.name: source_mu
column.description: The code that appears in the IgslReferences that describes where this data point comes from.

column.name: source_position
column.description: The code that appears in the IgslReferences that describes where the positional information comes from.

column.name: toggle_asc
column.description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is to be used for the Atittude Star Catalog.

table.name: tmass_original_valid
table.description:
2MASS PSC Catalogue
{\bf Reference paper:} Skrutskie et al. 2006, AJ 131, 1163
Documentation: http://www.ipac.caltech.edu/2mass/releases/allsky/doc/explsup.html
{\bf Original catalogue:} ftp://ftp.ipac.caltech.edu/pub/2mass/allsky

column.name: dec
column.description: J2000 declination with respect to the ICRS

column.name: ra
column.description: J2000 right ascension with respect to the ICRS

column.name: designation
column.description: Sexagesimal, equatorial position-based source name in the form: hmmssss+ddmmsss[ABC...] The prefix "2MASS J" in not explicitely listed in the designation.

column.name: err_ang
column.description: Position angle on the sky of the semi-major axis of the position uncertainty ellipse (East of North)

column.name: err_maj
column.description: Semi-major axis length of the one sigma position uncertainty ellipse

column.name: err_min
column.description: Semi-minor axis length of the one sigma position uncertainty ellipse

column.name: ext_key
column.description: Unique identification number of the record in the XSC (2MASS Extended Source Catalogue) that corresponds to this point source. Can be NULL if no corresponding extended source is present in the XSC.

column.name: h_m
column.description: Default H-band magnitude. \\ In case of a source not detected in the H-band, it is an upper limit and the corresponding total photometric uncertainty is NULL.\\ In case of a source detected in the H-band and with no useful brightness estimate, it is set to NULL.

column.name: h_msigcom
column.description: Total photometric uncertainty for the default H-band magnitude. This column is NULL if the default magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit (i.e. the source is not detected, or inconsistently deblended in the H-band).

column.name: j_date
column.description: The Julian Date of the source measurement accurate to +30 seconds. This value is extrapolated from the start time of the Survey scan using the difference between the declinations of the source and the first row in the Tile divided by the scanning rate of the telescope (approximately 5sec). The scanning rate of the two 2MASS telescopes was slightly different because of the need to optimize the dithering of images on the arrays.

column.name: j_m
column.description: Default J-band magnitude. \\ In case of a source not detected in the J-band, it is an upper limit and the corresponding total photometric uncertainty is NULL.\\ In case of a source detected in the J-band and with no useful brightness estimate, it is set to NULL.

column.name: j_msigcom
column.description: Total photometric uncertainty for the default J-band magnitude. This column is NULL if the default magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit (i.e. the source is not detected, or inconsistently deblended in the J-band).

column.name: k_m
column.description: Default K-band magnitude. \\ In case of a source not detected in the K-band, it is an upper limit and the corresponding total photometric uncertainty is NULL.\\ In case of a source detected in the K-band and with no useful brightness estimate, it is set to NULL.

column.name: k_msigcom
column.description: Total photometric uncertainty for the default K-band magnitude. This column is NULL if the default magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit (i.e. the source is not detected, or inconsistently deblended in the K-band.

column.name: ph_qual
tmass_oid
column.description: Incremental unique numeric identifier (increasing with declination). This is the only field which was not in the original 2MASS catalogue, but was added for cross-match purposes.

table.name: tgas_source
table.description: Subset of sources from gaia_source with non-null parallaxes

column.name: dec
column.description: Latitude (Declination) $\delta$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: parallax
column.description: Absolute stellar parallax $\varpi$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: parallax_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_\varpi$ of absolute stellar parallax at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: phot_g_mean_mag
column.description: Mean magnitude in the G band. This is computed from the G-band mean flux applying the magnitude zero-point in the AB scale. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

column.name: pmdec
column.description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}: $\mu_{\delta}$

column.name: pmra
column.description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Right Ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}: $\mu_{\alpha*}$

column.name: ra
column.description: Longitude (Right Ascension) $\alpha$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: random_index
column.description:
Random index which can be used in order to select smaller subsets of the data that are still representative. This can be useful for validation (testing on 10 different random subsets), visualization (displaying 1% of the data) and exploring the data, without having to load/download all data.
The column should have non-repeating/unique long, preferably without any missing numbers between 0 and N-1 (where N is the numbers of rows).
This column should be just a counter which gets populated in a totatly random way.

column.name: astrometric_chi2_ac
column.description:
Astrometric goodness-of-fit ($\chi^2$) in the AC direction.
These $\chi^2$ values were computed for all accepted observations of the source, without taking into account the source $\tt excessNoise$ (if any). They do however take into account the attitude excess noise (if any) of each observation.

column.name: astrometric_chi2_al
column.description:
Astrometric goodness-of-fit ($\chi^2$) in the AL direction.
These $\chi^2$ values were computed for all accepted observations of the source, without taking into account the source $\tt excessNoise$ (if any). They do however take into account the attitude excess noise (if any) of each observation.

column.name: astrometric_delta_q
column.description:
In the HTPM solution $\tt deltaQ$ indicates the discrepancy between the Hipparcos data and the Gaia data when a single model of uniform space motion is fitted to both datasets. A large value of $\tt deltaQ$ could indicate non-linear motion (e.g.\ in a binary).
$\tt deltaQ$ shows how much the $\chi^2$ of the joint solution increases by fitting a single set of five astrometric parameters to the data, rather than two independent sets of five parameter each. See D. Michalik et al. 2014, \emph{Joint astrometric solution of Hipparcos and Gaia: A recipe for the Hundred Thousand Proper Motions project} (submitted to A\&A) for details.

column.name: astrometric_excess_noise
column.description:
This is the excess noise $\epsilon_i$ of the source. It measures how much the assumed observational noise in each observation must be (quadratically) increased in order to give $\chi^2=\nu$ in the astrometric solution of the source. A value of 0 signifies that the source is astrometrically well-behaved, i.e.\ that the residuals of the fit statistically agree with the assumed observational noise ($\chi^2\le\nu$).
The significance of $\tt excessNoise$ is given by $\tt excessNoiseSig$. If ${\tt excessNoiseSig}\le 2$ then $\tt excessNoise$ is probably not significant, and the source may be astrometrically well-behaved even if $\tt excessNoise$ is large.
Independent of the given value of $\tt excessNoise$, the `gaussianized chi-square $\tt f2$ is always calculated using ${\tt excessNoise}=0$.
The excess source noise is further explained in Sects.~3.6 and 5.1.2 of \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

column.name: astrometric_excess_noise_sig
column.description: A dimensionless measure ($D$) of the significance of the calculated $\tt excessNoise$ ($\epsilon_i$). A value $D>2$ indicates that the given $\tt excessNoise$ is probably significant.

column.name: astrometric_go_f
column.description:
$	t f2$ is the `gaussianized chi-square indicating the goodness-of-fit of the astrometric solution to the accepted data. For good fits, $	t f2$ should approximately follow a normal distribution with zero mean value and unit standard deviation. $	t f2$ values exceeding, say, +3 thus indicate a bad fit to the data. An alternative indicator of bad fits is the $	t excessNoise$ (see below).
The statistic $	t f2$ was computed from the goodness-of-fit statistic $\chi^2$ (see below) and $
u$, the number of degrees of freedom, according to the formula:
${m f2}=(9
u/2)^{1/2} [(\chi^2/
u)^{1/3} + 2 / (9
u) -1]$
This formula is the well-known cube-root transformation of the chi-square variable (E.B. Wilson \& M.M. Hilferty 1931, Proc. National Academy of Science, 17, 684). It is usually quoted to be valid for $
u > 30$, but is in fact useful for much smaller $
u$. The transformation of $(\chi^2,
u)$ to f2 eliminates the inconvenience of having the distribution (and hence the significance levels) depend on the additional variable $
u$, which is generally not the same for different sources.
For a source update with $N$ astrometric parameters (see ${	t paramsSolved}$), $\chi^2$ and $
u$ were computed as
$\chi^2 = {	t chi2}[0] + {	t chi2}[1]$,
$
u = {	t nObs}[0] + {	t nObs}[1] - N$.
The `unit weight error of the solution is given by $(\chi^2/
u)^{1/2}$, which is expected to be $\simeq 1.0$ for a good solution, but unlike f2 its distribution still depends on $
u$.
In AGIS the source update deals with bad fits (large $	t f2$) by adding $	t excessNoise$ to the formal observation noise. This effectively reduces the unit weight error of the fit to 1.0 and inflates the covariance of the estimated astrometric parameters correspondingly. However, the chi-square values ${	t chi2}[]$ used to calculate $	t f2$ do not take into account the $	t excessNoise$, and $	t f2$ can therefore always be used as a goodness-of-fit indicator of the source solution in AGIS. The excessNoise provides an alternative indicator of bad fits, although it may be 0 for good fits (unit weight error $\le 1$, roughly corresponding to negative $	t f2$). The actual amount of excess noise used in the fit (and covariance calculation) is given by $	t excessNoise$ if ${	t excessNoiseSig}>2$, otherwise it is 0 (even though $	t excessNoise$ may be positive).

column.name: astrometric_n_obs_ac
column.description: Total number of observations (= CCD transits) in AC that contributed to the astrometric solution of the source. The total number of observations may decrease as outliers are detected so this number refers to the total number of observations minus the number of outliers.

column.name: astrometric_n_obs_al
column.description: Total number of observations (= CCD transits) AL that contributed to the astrometric solution of the source. The total number of observations may decrease as outliers are detected so this number refers to the total number of observations minus the number of outliers.

column.name: astrometric_n_outliers_ac
column.description: Total number of outlier observations (= CCD transits) in AC (second element). Identified outliers were downweighted and did not contribute to the update of the source. An observation was regarded as an outlier if the downweighting factor was $<0.2$.

column.name: astrometric_n_outliers_al
column.description: Total number of outlier observations (= CCD transits) in AL. Identified outliers were downweighted and did not contribute to the update of the source. An observation was regarded as an outlier if the downweighting factor was $<0.2$.

column.name: astrometric_params_solved
column.description:
The 6 least-significant bits of ${\tt paramsSolved}$ indicate which astrometric parameters have been estimated for this source. A set bit means the parameter was updated, an unset bit means the parameter was not updated. The least-significant bit corresponds to $\alpha$. The table below shows the values of ${\tt paramsSolved}$ for relevant combinations of the parameters.
Each AGIS run starts with a target number $N$ (usually = 5) of astrometric parameters to solve for, with the following mapping:
\begin{tabular}{lccccccc} $N$ & ${\tt paramsSolved}$ & $\alpha$ & $\delta$ & $\varpi$ & $\mu_{\alpha*}$ & $\mu_\delta $ & $\mu_r$ \\\hline 2 & 3 & $\times$ & $\times$ & & & & \\ 3 & 7 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & & & \\ 4 & 27 & $\times$ & $\times$ & & $\times$ & $\times$ & \\ 5 & 31 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & \\ 6 & 63 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$\\\hline \end{tabular}
For each source, however, an $N$-parameter update could fail (e.g.\ because there is an insufficient number of observations or their temporal distribution does not allow the update) and in this case a fallback option with a smaller value of $N$ is attempted.

column.name: astrometric_primary_flag
column.description: Flag indicating if this source was used as a primary source ($\tt true$) or secondary source ($\tt false$). Only primary sources contribute to the estimation of attitude, calibration, and global parameters. The estimation of source parameters is otherwise done in exactly the same way for primary and secondary sources.

column.name: astrometric_priors_used
column.description: Type of prior used in the astrometric solution: \begin{itemize} \item 0: No prior used \item 1: Galaxy Bayesian Prior for parallax and proper motion \item 2: Galaxy Bayesian Prior for parallax and proper motion relaxed by factor 10 \item 3: Hipparcos prior for position \item 4: Hipparcos prior for position and proper motion \item 5: Tycho2 prior for position \item 6: Quasar prior for proper motion \end{itemize}

column.name: astrometric_rank_defect
column.description: The rank defect of the astrometric solution of the source. This should normally be zero, signaling that the rank of the least-squares system for the solution equals the number of estimated parameters (the binary digit sum of ${\tt paramsSolved}$). A positive value means that the astrometric solution of the source is most likely wrong.

column.name: astrometric_relegation_factor
column.description: Relegation factor of the source calculated as per Eq.~(118) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain} used for the primary selection process.

column.name: astrometric_weight_ac
column.description:
mean astrometric weight of the source in the AC direction
The mean astrometric weight of the source is calculated as per Eq.~(119) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

column.name: astrometric_weight_al
column.description:
mean astrometric weight of the source in the ALdirection.
The mean astrometric weight of the source is calculated as per Eq.~(119) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

column.name: dec_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_\delta$ of latitude (Declination) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: dec_parallax_corr
column.description: Correlation between declination and parallax in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: dec_pmdec_corr
column.description: Correlation between declination and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: dec_pmra_corr
column.description: Correlation between declination and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: matched_observations
column.description:
A given source will never be removed from the MDB catalog. Instead, it may simply be left without any matched observation, thus indicating that this source has e.g. been splitted into two, or that it may have been a parasitic source wrongly created in IDT.
This field indicates the number of observations (detection transits) that have been matched to a given Source during the last XM revision.
In particular, matchedObservations = 0 indicates a Source which has been merged to another one by IDU XM, MDB Integrator, etc.
Also, it is proposed to use matchedObservations = -1 to indicate that a given source has never been observed by Gaia (but it was included in the catalog from the IGSL, etc).

column.name: parallax_pmdec_corr
column.description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: parallax_pmra_corr
column.description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: phot_g_mean_flux
column.description: Mean flux in the G-band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

column.name: phot_g_mean_flux_error
column.description: Error on the mean flux in the G-band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

column.name: phot_g_n_obs
column.description: Number of observations that contributed to the G mean flux and mean flux error. This number will be set to 0 if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

column.name: phot_variable_flag
pmdec_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\delta}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: pmra_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\alpha*}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing right ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

column.name: pmra_pmdec_corr
column.description: Correlation between proper motion right ascension and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ra_dec_corr
column.description: Correlation between right ascension and declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ra_error
column.description: Standard error $\sigma_\alpha *$ of longitude (Right Ascension) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch} times $\cos(\delta)$.

column.name: ra_parallax_corr
column.description: Correlation between right ascension and parallax in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ra_pmdec_corr
column.description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ra_pmra_corr
column.description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

column.name: ref_epoch
column.description: The reference epoch to which the astrometic source parameters are referred to expressed as a Julian Year in TCB.

column.name: scan_direction_mean_k1
column.description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
scanDirectionMean[$k-1$] is an angle between $-180^\circ/k$ and $+180^\circ/k$, giving the mean position angle of the scans at order $k$.
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

column.name: scan_direction_mean_k2
column.description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.

The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

column.name: scan_direction_strength_k1
column.description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

column.name: source_id
column.description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

table.name: gaia_hip_tycho2_match
table.description: Tabel created to provide CU9 with information regarding the XM used in TGAS between Gaia and TYCHO2/HIP Sources.

column.name: hyp_tyc_oid
column.description: Additional numeric unique identifier of the Gaia source, numerical TYCHO2/HIP sourceId as defined in the IGSL SourceCatalogIds table

column.name: original_ext_source_id
column.description: The TYCHO2/HIP sourceId as a ?String as it appeared in the original catalogues

column.name: source_id
column.description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source, following BAS-020 format using the GaiaTools sourceId generator utilities.

column.name: ext_cat_solution_type
column.description: N = normal treatment, close stars were subtracted when possible. D = double star treatment. Two stars were found. The companion is normally included as a separate Tycho-2 entry, but may have been rejected. P = photocentre treatment, close stars were not subtracted. This special treatment was applied to known or suspected doubles which were not successfully (or reliably) resolved in the Tycho-2 double star processing.

column.name: solution_id
column.description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

table.name: hipparcos_newreduction
table.description:
Hipparcos New Reduction: The Astrometric Catalogue
Hipparcos, the new Reduction of the Raw data van Leeuwen F. Astron. Astrophys. 474, 653 (2007) http://dx.doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361:20078357
A new reduction of the astrometric data as produced by the Hipparcos mission has been published, claiming accuracies for nearly all stars brighter than magnitude Hp=8 to be better, by up to a factor 4, than in the original catalogue.
The new Hipparcos astrometric catalogue is checked for the quality of the data and the consistency of the formal errors as well as the possible presence of error correlations. The differences with the earlier publication are explained.
Methods. The internal errors are followed through the reduction process, and the external errors are investigated on the basis of a comparison with radio observations of a small selection of stars, and the distribution of negative parallaxes. Error correlation levels are investigated and the reduction by more than a factor 10 as obtained in the new catalogue is explained.
Results. The formal errors on the parallaxes for the new catalogue are confirmed. The presence of a small amount of additional noise, though unlikely, cannot be ruled out.
Conclusions. The new reduction of the Hipparcos astrometric data provides an improvement by a factor 2.2 in the total weight compared to the catalogue published in 1997, and provides much improved data for a wide range of studies on stellar luminosities and local galactic kinematics.

column.name: sn
column.description:
[0,159] Solution type new reduction
The solution type is a number 10xd+s consisting of two parts d and s: - s describes the type of solution adopted: 1 = stochastic solution (dispersion is given in the 'var' column) 3 = VIM solution (additional parameters in file hipvim.dat) 5 = 5-parameter solution (this file) 7 = 7-parameter solution (additional parameters in hip7p.dat) 9 = 9-parameter solution (additional parameters in hip9p.dat) - d describes peculiarities, as a combination of values: 0 = single star 1 = double star 2 = variable in the system with amplitude > 0.2mag 4 = astrometry refers to the photocenter 8 = measurements concern the secondary (fainter) in the double system

column.name: so
column.description:
[0,5] Solution type old reduction
as follows: 0 = standard 5-parameter solution 1 = 7- or 9-parameter solution 2 = stochastic solution 3 = double and multiple stars 4 = orbital binary as resolved in the published catalog 5 = VIM (variability-induced mover) solution

column.name: u1
column.description:
Upper-triangular weight matrix element 1
The upper-triangular weight matrix U is related to the covariance matrix C by C-1 = ∼U U (∼U represents transposed U) The elements Ui forming the upper triangular matrix are stored as ± -+ | (1) (2) (4) (7) (11) | | 0 (3) (5) (8) (12) | | 0 0 (6) (9) (13) | | 0 0 0 (10) (14) | | 0 0 0 0 (15) | ± -+ on the astrometric parameters RA, Dec, plx, pmRA, pmDE, and derivatives of proper motions for 7- and 9-parameter solutions.

column.description:

The upper-triangular weight matrix U is related to the covariance matrix C by C-1 = ∼U U (∼U represents transposed U) The elements Ui forming the upper triangular matrix are stored as ± -+ | (1) (2) (4) (7) (11) | | 0 (3) (5) (8) (12) | | 0 0 (6) (9) (13) | | 0 0 0 (10) (14) | | 0 0 0 0 (15) | ± -+ on the astrometric parameters RA, Dec, plx, pmRA, pmDE, and derivatives of proper motions for 7- and 9-parameter solutions.

column.name: va
column.description: [0,2] Reference to variability annex

column.name: var
column.description: Cosmic dispersion added (stochastic solution)

column.name: v_i
column.description: V-I colour index

column.name: id_epc
column.description: The IDs in the Gaia Ecliptic Pole Catalogue Version (GEPC 3.0) given as IAU standards: JHHMMSS.SS+DDMMSS.S.

column.name: id_gsc23
column.description: These are the IDs as published in the various input catalogs converted to a big integer. For the GSC23 we have had to alter slightly the name,specifically: GSC2.3 objects have original names that are combination of region names and running number, e.g. S00000001 is the first object in the region S0000000, we have converted the region names to the ``official' numerical values in the htm level 6 structure, hence the smallest is S0000000 = 32768 and N3333333 = 65535 is the highest.

column.name: id_hip
column.description: If the source is a Hipparcos star this field contains the Hipparcos number.

column.name: id_lqrf
column.description: These are the running number in the Gaia Initial Quasar Catalog - version 4 - updated September 2011 - GIQC\_4.

column.name: id_ogle
column.description: The OGLE ID is given by a combination of \\ A region of sky identifier (RI) equal to 10, 11, 12, 13, 14 corresponding to map names blg, car, cen, lmc, mus.\\ The file running number ( NNN.N) \\ The running number in the file (RN) \\ The ID is defined as: long(string(RI)+string(NNN.N * 10000))+RN.

column.name: id_ppmxl
column.description: These are the IDs as published in the PPMXL, the ipix Identifier (Q3C ipix of the USNO-B 1.0 object) converted to a big integer.

column.name: id_sdss
column.description: These are the IDs as published in the SDSS DR9 in big integer format.

column.name: id_tmass
column.description: The Two Mass provided the names in a IAU standard fashion of 2MASS JHHMMSS.S +DDMMSS.S these were codeified as +HHMMSSSDDMMSSS.

column.name: id_tycho
column.description: These are the IDs as published in Tycho2. In TYCHO-2 objects were identified by 3 numbers (TYC1,TYC2 and TYC3) and we have combined these into one complete number given by (TYC1*1000000.0d0)+(TYC2*10.0d0)+(TYC3*1.0d0)

column.name: id_ucac
column.description: These are the IDs as published in the UCAC4 specfically a running star ID number.

column.name: solution_id
column.description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...
